qa.q: What do you do exactly?
qa.a: I’m a Product & UX Designer who focuses on simplifying complex product problems into intuitive flows and interfaces. I work across the full cycle—understanding the problem, structuring flows, designing UI, validating with users, and handing off to engineering. My strength is converting unclear requirements into structured, build-ready solutions.

qa.q: How many years of experience do you have?
qa.a: I have around 5 years of experience across B2C, B2B, SaaS and enterprise products. My work spans mobile apps, dashboards, redesigns, and design systems.

qa.q: Which industries have you worked in?
qa.a: Telecom, Fintech, Travel, Consumer Apps, Insights Platforms, and Enterprise SaaS. This range helps me design for both everyday consumers and specialized power users.

qa.q: What products have you worked on?
qa.a: Consumer apps, telecom purchase flows, onboarding journeys, dashboards, fintech tools, and enterprise systems. My strengths lie in clarity-heavy experiences.

qa.q: Which project shows your strongest problem-solving?
qa.a: The PIC Dashboard. It required reorganizing dense, analytical content into a simple insights-driven model. It shows clarity, system-thinking, information hierarchy and UX depth.

qa.q: What is your most detailed case study?
qa.a: The Verizon PDP redesign is my most detailed end-to-end case study. It covers hierarchy cleanup, mobile-first improvements, flow restructuring, and design clarity.

qa.q: Do you have B2C examples?
qa.a: Yes—my CC App onboarding redesign reduced friction by distributing steps contextually across the experience.

qa.q: Do you have B2B/dashboard examples?
qa.a: Yes—PIC Dashboard is my strongest dashboard example. Cashfree dashboard is another example of flow simplification.

qa.q: What’s your design process?
qa.a: Problem → Flow → Wireframes → Test → UI → QA → Launch. I start with structure, clarify goals, validate assumptions, iterate quickly, and then refine visuals.

qa.q: What’s your approach to problem-framing?
qa.a: I break unclear requirements into flows, decision points, and assumptions. Once the problem is structured, the design becomes straightforward.

qa.q: Do you work on UX and UI both?
qa.a: Yes—flows, logic, structure, wireframes, UI, interactions, copywriting, and handoff. I handle end-to-end product design.

qa.q: How do you work with PMs?
qa.a: Through early alignment on goals, constraints, assumptions, and success metrics. I keep PMs updated frequently to avoid surprises.

qa.q: How do you collaborate with engineers?
qa.a: I involve engineers early for feasibility, share flows before UI, and help QA with build validation. I keep files clean and easy to read.

qa.q: How do you communicate design decisions?
qa.a: With clear reasoning—what users needed, what problem was solved, and why an approach works. I avoid jargon and use flows & examples.

qa.q: How do you think about mobile design?
qa.a: Clarity, thumb reach, minimal friction, and progressive disclosure. I prioritize what users need most and reduce effort wherever possible.

qa.q: Do you work on onboarding flows?
qa.a: Yes—I redesigned the CC App onboarding to make it lighter and more contextual, guiding users naturally with minimal friction.

qa.q: Have you worked on dashboards?
qa.a: Yes—PIC Dashboard and Cashfree. These projects required clarity, data simplification, insight-first layouts, and flexible design systems.

qa.q: How do you design for power users?
qa.a: Speed, hierarchy, reducing friction, shortcut-friendly layouts, and minimal cognitive load. I reorganize flows so users reach insights in fewer steps.

qa.q: Have you built design systems?
qa.a: Yes—the PIC Design System, including tokens, variants, spacing, documentation, and developer alignment.

qa.q: What did you learn about design systems?
qa.a: If nobody maintains a design system, it dies. I set up processes to ensure components stay updated and consistent across builds.

qa.q: Do you do research?
qa.a: Yes—light interviews, heuristic reviews, usability tests, and validating assumptions with real users. Research is a tool, not a formality.

qa.q: Do you conduct usability tests?
qa.a: Yes—quick prototypes, friction checks, and evaluating clarity. It helps refine flows before development.

qa.q: What values matter to you?
qa.a: Clarity, respect, ownership, open communication, and collaborative problem solving.

qa.q: What kind of teammate are you?
qa.a: Supportive, calm, structured, and collaborative. I help teams align and move without chaos.

qa.q: What roles are you looking for?
qa.a: Product Designer roles where I can own features end-to-end and work closely with engineering and PMs to create impactful experiences.

qa.q: Where do you see yourself in 2–3 years?
qa.a: More specialized in data-heavy UX, system design, and leading clarity-driven product decisions.
